column1: ap 06:30|6.30|"And so it came about that that particular Mid-Term Service-Day match
made history. Big scores had often been put up on Mid-Term Service Day.
Games had frequently been one-sided. But it had never happened before in
the annals of the school that one side
column2: going in first early in the

column1: morning
column2: had neither completed its innings nor declared it closed when

column1: stumps were drawn at 6.30. In no previous Sedleigh match
day's play
column2: had the pathetic words ""Did not bat"" been written against

column1: the whole of one of the contending teams."|"Mike and Psmith"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap > 11:00|"shortly after eleven o'clock"|"The Old Boys' match was timed to begin shortly after eleven o'clock.
During the interval most of the school walked across the field to look
at the pitch. One or two of the Old Boys had already changed and were
practicing in front of the pavilion."|"Mike and Psmith"|"P. G. Wodehouse"
ap 01:05|"five minutes after one"|"MIKE RECEIVES A COMMISSION
There is only one thing to be said in favor of detention on a fine
summer's afternoon
column2: and that is that it is very pleasant to come out of.

column1: The sun never seems so bright or the turf so green as during the first
five minutes after one has come out of the detention room. One feels as
if one were entering a new and very delightful world. There is also a
touch of the Rip van Winkle feeling. Everything seems to have gone on
and left one behind. Mike
column2: as he walked to the cricket field

column1: much behind the times."|"Mike and Psmith"|"P. G. Wodehouse"
00:00|midnight|"Mike recognized Adair's voice. The last person he would have expected to
meet at midnight obviously on the point of going for a bicycle ride."|"Mike and Psmith"|"P. G. Wodehouse"
01:00|"one o'clock
in the morning"|"""Nothing that happens in this loony bin
surprise me now. There was a time when I might have thought it a little
unusual to have to leave the house through a canvas chute at one o'clock
in the morning
column2: but I suppose it's quite the regular thing here. Old

column1: school tradition
so accustomed to jumping out of windows that they look on it as a sort
of affectation to go out by the door. I suppose none of you merchants
can give me any idea when the next knockabout entertainment of this kind
is likely to take place?"""|"Mike and Psmith"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

ap 10:45|quarter-to-eleven|"Mr. Downing was perhaps the most bigoted anti-gym-shoeist in the whole
list of English schoolmasters. He waged war remorselessly against gym
shoes. Satire
column4: detention—every weapon was employed by him

column1: in dealing with their wearers. It had been the late Dunster's practice
always to go over to school in gym shoes when
felt shaky in the morning's lesson. Mr. Downing always detected him in
the first five minutes
column2: and that meant a lecture of anything from ten

column1: minutes to a quarter of an hour on Untidy Habits and Boys Who Looked
Like Loafers—which broke the back of the morning's work nicely. On one
occasion
column2: when a particularly tricky bit of Livy was on the bill of

column1: fare
column2: Dunster had entered the form room in heelless Turkish bath

column1: slippers
column2: of a vivid crimson; and the subsequent proceedings

column1: his journey over to the house to change the heelless atrocities
seen him through very nearly to the quarter-to-eleven interval."|"Mike and Psmith"|"P. G. Wodehouse"
